user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimerGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_TimerGetInfo(osal_id_t timer_id, OS_timer_prop_t *timer_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *           record;
    int32                          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t                 objtype;
    OS_object_token_t              token;
    OS_timecb_internal_record_t *  timecb;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *timebase;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timer_prop);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    memset(timer_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_timer_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, timer_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_timecb_table, token);
        timecb   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timecb_table, token);
        timebase = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, timecb->timebase_token);

        strncpy(timer_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timer_prop->name) - 1);
        timer_prop->creator       = record->creator;
        timer_prop->interval_time = (uint32)timecb->interval_time;
        timer_prop->accuracy      = timebase->accuracy_usec;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_TimerGetInfo:
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    uint32    start_time;
    uint32    interval_time;
    uint32    accuracy;
} OS_timer_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char              timer_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    uint32            flags;
    OS_object_token_t timebase_token;
    osal_id_t         prev_cb;
    osal_id_t         next_cb;
    uint32            backlog_resets;
    int32             wait_time;
    int32             interval_time;
    OS_ArgCallback_t  callback_ptr;
    void *            callback_arg;
} OS_timecb_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char           timebase_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_TimerSync_t external_sync;
    uint32         accuracy_usec;
    osal_id_t      first_cb;
    uint32         freerun_time;
    uint32         nominal_start_time;
    uint32         nominal_interval_time;
} OS_timebase_internal_record_t
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_timecb_table
...
OS_timecb_internal_record_t OS_timecb_table[OS_MAX_TIMERS]
...
extern OS_timebase_internal_record_t OS_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
memset(timer_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_timer_prop_t));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated in this function as written: memset(timer_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_timer_prop_t)) writes exactly sizeof(OS_timer_prop_t) bytes to the object referenced by the parameter timer_prop, and the parameter is typed as OS_timer_prop_t * (the type is defined and known). The code also checks the pointer for NULL (OS_CHECK_POINTER). This is safe provided callers respect the API and pass a pointer to an OS_timer_prop_t object. A violation scenario would be if a caller passed a pointer to a smaller object or to the middle of another object (for example &some_struct.some_field where the remaining bytes are less than sizeof(OS_timer_prop_t)) — then the memset would access beyond the bounds and violate Rule 21.17.
